statement:
\[thm:one\]There are an infinite number of primes congruent to
$3 \pmod 4$.

Choose any prime $p\equiv 3\pmod 4$; we find a prime of that form that
exceeds $p$. $$N=(2^2\cdot 3\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdots p) - 1$$ Clearly
$N\equiv 3\pmod 4$, and thus must have at least one prime factor that is
also $\equiv 3\pmod 4$. But $N$ is not divisible by any prime less than
or equal to $p$, so must be divisible by some prime congruent to
$3\pmod 4$ that exceeds $p$.

\[thm:two\]There are an infinite number of primes congruent to
$1\pmod 4$.

Given $N>1$, we find a prime $p>N$ with $p\equiv 1\pmod 4$. Let $p$ be
the smallest (odd) prime factor of $(N!)^2+1$; note that $p>N$. Now
$$(N!)^2\equiv -1\pmod p$$ and therefore
$$(N!)^{p-1}\equiv (-1)^{(p-1)/2}\pmod p.$$ By Fermat’s little theorem,
$(N!)^{p-1}\equiv 1\pmod p$, so we have
$$(-1)^{(p-1)/2}\equiv 1\pmod p$$ The left-hand side cannot be -1, since
then $0\equiv 2\pmod p$. Thus $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=1$ and it follows that
$p\equiv 1\pmod 4$.

Note that the variant of Euclid’s proof of the infinitude of primes used
in the proof of Theorem \[thm:one\] does not work for Theorem
\[thm:two\], since we cannot conclude that an integer $\equiv 1\pmod 4$
has a factor of the same kind.

[10]{} Apostol, T *Introduction to Analytic Number Theory*, Springer
1976.
